Title: Collaborative Research: SusCHEM: Hybrid mixed-resolution solvation models for chemical processing in ionic liquids

A major bottleneck in the quest for large-scale replacement of petroleum feedstocks with ones derived from cellulosic biomass is the difficulty posed by the physical, chemical, and biological pretreatments that are necessary for converting the native biomass into industrially-useful feedstocks. And while the mechanical and biological pretreatment routes are largely well understood, substantial uncertainty remains in how to chemically pretreat biomass to enable further processing. The goal of this collaborative project is to advance multiscale models of molecular solvation to better understand dissolution of cellulosic biomass in ionic liquids. Ionic liquids are an important class of materials, which have a broad spectrum of applications. The project will (i) apply multiscale solvent models to ionic liquids; (ii) establish the use of X-ray solution scattering experiments to validate multiscale models; (iii) apply these models to understand why small concentrations of dissolved water limit cellulose dissolution; and (iv) integrate research with education and outreach efforts to advance cross-disciplinary training and broaden STEM participation.

The proposed research will elucidate the fundamental relationships between ionic liquid structure and performance, and how these relationships depend on temperature and water content. These dependencies are key to enabling the rational engineering of ionic liquids for robust performance during chemical processing in ionic liquids. The computational techniques that will be developed will link the microscopic details with macroscopic behavior using a novel multiscale approach that drastically reduces the computational costs associated with atomistic molecular dynamics and coarse-grained simulations. By reducing the number of atoms present in the system, the cost of calculating electrostatic forces, the dominant cost in molecular dynamics simulations of charged systems, will be greatly reduced, allowing for much larger and longer simulations with the same set of available computational resources. This approach will allow for much more in-depth studies of the interactions between ionic liquids and cellulose than is currently possible. The ultimate objective is the identification of the dominant criteria for selecting ionic liquids that will enable the design of more economical and more efficient chemical processes for cellulose dissolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellulose is contained in natural biomass, such as sawdust or cornstalks, and is an underutilized source of energy.  This cellulose-containing biomass can be converted into liquid biofuels, such as ethanol.  If the conversion of cellulose to ethanol can be done economically, these green biofuels may play a small part in transforming our future energy sources into more sustainable and renewable ones.  The demand for ethanol in our society continues to increase, as the public has observed with increasing ethanol content in our gasoline.  To economically convert cellulose into biofuel, the cellulose must be broken down into its individual components, or cellulose strands (i.e., cellulose must be dissolved).  Once the cellulose is dissolved, the individual strands can be effectively converted to ethanol via enzymatic or catalytic reactions. 

 

Ionic liquids (IL) are a class of solvents that consist of a cation and anion.  These ILs are typically thermally stable, have low melting points, and are essentially non-volatile [1].  They can be combined with a co-solvent, such as water, which can change the original properties of the ILs.  In general, the properties of ILs are very dependent on the cation, anion, and co-solvent combinations. Many of the ILs are effective solvents in the chemical industry, but they are expensive [2,3], so being able to minimize their concentration by using them with a co-solvent is economically beneficial.  Many ILs, such as imidazolium-based ILs, are not capable of dissolving cellulose even with low water concentrations at moderate temperatures [1, 4-7].

 

From experiments, tetrabutylphosphonium hydroxide (TBPH)-water and tetrabutylphosphonium chloride (TBPCl)-dimethylformamide (DMF) mixtures have been shown to be capable of dissolving cellulose at high co-solvent concentrations. Therefore, this research utilized molecular dynamics simulations to study the mechanisms and critical properties of cellulose dissolution in the TBPCl-water solution at high water concentrations. This study determined that the TBPCl-water solution can utilize water in the cellulose dissolution process; however, once the water concentration is very high, cellulose dissolution fails. Specifically, this research found a critical hydrogen bonding strength threshold (i.e., the hydrogen bonding lifetime of the anion?cellulose hydroxyl hydrogens), which can be utilized to determine a theoretical maximum water concentration above which a specific IL-water combination would fail to dissolve cellulose.  However, this is not the only determining factor in the cellulose dissolution, as the cation and co-solvent also play a role in the cellulose dissolution process.

 

While water does negatively impact the TBPCl-water mixture?s ability to dissolve cellulose, it also seems to play a critical role in the cellulose dissolution process. Thus a pocket is formed between the dissolving strand and the cellulose bundle by insertion of water molecules, which provides a lag time for the larger TBP cation to move in and more permanently dissolve the cellulose strand.  Water also stays in these water pockets for longer times since the water can form hydrogen bonds with the cellulose strands, a property that can be calculated from these simulations.  The crucial properties mentioned above may be programmed into future simulations that search for more economical and environmentally friendly IL-water combinations. Moreover, machine learning algorithms could be used to speed-up the search time and minimize experimental testing and cost.  Therefore, the properties that were determined from this study and the research of many others can provide a pathway for future researches to rapidly design future IL-water combinations while minimizing the experiential cost of evaluating all the possible IL-water combinations.

 

 

[1] Fang, Z., Smith, R. L., Jr., Qi, Z., Eds. Production of Biofuels and Chemicals with Ionic Liquids; Springer: Heidelberg, 2014.

[2] Center for Sustainable Systems, University of Michigan, "Biofuels Factsheet". CSS08-09. http://css.umich.edu/factsheets/biofuels-factsheet, 2019.

[3] Ren, P.; Ponder, J. W. Dissolution of cellulose in ionic liquid: A review. AIP Conference Proceedings 2017, 1809, 020035.

[4] Mazza, M.; Catana, D.-A.; Vaca-Garcia, C.; Cecutti, C. Influence of water on the dissolution of cellulose in selected ionic liquids. Cellulose 2009, 16(2), 207-215.

[5] Swatloski, R. P.; Spear, S. J.; Holbrey, J. D.; Rogers, R. D. Dissolution of Cellulose with Ionic Liquids. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2002, 124(18), 4974-4975.

[6] Viell, J.; Marquardt, W. Disintegration and dissolution kinetics of wood chips in ionic liquids. Holzforschung 2011, 65(4), 519-525.

[7] Wang, H.; Gurau, G.; Rogers, R. D. Ionic liquid processing of cellulose. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41(4), 1519-1537.
